Situation1: They casually answer a mentee’s occasional questions during breaks.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Hand-delivering a high-value or sensitive package directly to the recipient and verifying their identity
Story: I was sitting in the break room, sipping my coffee, when my mentee, Jamie, slid into the seat across from me. “Hey, can I ask you something about the new inventory system?” Jamie’s eyes were hopeful, and I knew how much they relied on these quick chats to learn the ropes. I started explaining the process, trying to break it down simply, when my phone buzzed. It was a notification: a high-value package had just arrived, and I was the only one available to deliver it. The protocol was strict—no delays, hand it directly to the recipient, verify their ID, and log the delivery immediately. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “No exceptions with these packages.” Jamie was still looking at me, waiting for guidance, and I could see the confusion in their eyes as I hesitated. I felt torn, the weight of responsibility pressing from both sides—one expecting my knowledge, the other demanding my immediate action. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which role to honor first, feeling the tension coil tighter with every passing second.
